As a sommelier, one of the most important aspects of pairing wine with food is finding a wine that complements or counterbalances the characteristics of the dish. For example, a rich and fatty dish may call for a wine with high acidity to cut through the richness, while a delicate and subtle dish may require a wine with a more subtle flavor profile to avoid overpowering the flavors of the food.

For a dish that is rich and savory, such as roasted lamb or beef, I would suggest pairing it with a wine that has a bold and full-bodied character to match the intensity of the dish. One niche option that I would recommend is the Aglianico del Vulture, a red wine from the Basilicata region of southern Italy. This wine is made from the Aglianico grape and is known for its robust tannins, deep color, and complex flavors of dark fruit, leather, and spices. The wine has a long and persistent finish, which makes it a great choice to pair with the bold flavors of roasted meats.

On the other hand, for a lighter and more delicate dish, such as grilled fish or a salad, a wine with a more subtle flavor profile would be more appropriate. One option I would suggest is a Txakolina from the Basque Country in Spain. This white wine is made from the indigenous Hondarrabi Zuri grape and is known for its bright acidity and crisp minerality. It has flavors of green apple, lemon, and lime with a slight effervescence, making it a refreshing and light choice for a summer meal. The wine pairs well with seafood and salads, as its acidity helps to cut through the delicate flavors of the dish without overpowering them.
